moves.1. e4 c5 2. d4 cxd4 3. c3 dxc3 4. Nxc3: The initial phase of Morra's Gambit. The idea is to mobilize the pieces quickly to good squares and to get Black out of book and make uncoordinated moves--which usually happens. A pawn is sacrificed to do this however.
moves.4... Nc6 5. Bc4 e6 6. Nf3 Bb4: Bb4? This bishop is needed for defense and not put into a position for trading for White's weak bishop, or worse, the knight on c3.
moves.7. O-O Nge7 8. Bf4 a6 9. Bd6: Bd6! Already pressuring  Black's poor set-up.
moves.9... Bxc3 10. bxc3: Leaving the very strong bishop at d6 and trading his strongest piece.
moves.10... b5 11. Bb3 Na5 12. Qd3 Nxb3 13. ax: Not even an isolated pawn anymore for compensation. These pawns are strong and the rook is now activated--but the queenside is not where I'm going to be.
moves.13... Bb7 14. Rfd1: The d file can't be contested now. His dark squares are very weak because of the missing bishop.
moves.14... Bc6 15. Ne5 f6 16. Nxc6 Nxc6 17. Q: What else?  White has an unusual advantage for being a pawn down, but something has to be done immediately with it.
I'm thinking of tripling up on the d file with the queen but a continuation I looked at had me not only losing the advantage but the game as well! The exchanges led to Black queening a pawn with his knight protecting it.
moves.25. f4: f4! to start busting up that weak king on the f file.
moves.25... Qe8 26. f5 a5 27. Bc5 b4: b4? There is no time for that.
moves.28. Rd3d6: This didn't trigger any worries for Black so perhaps another won pawn will help...
moves.28... bxc3 29. Rxf6+: Rxd6!! A shot. The king is undefended and I'm also being pressured on the queen-side so this move became very necessary.
moves.29... Kxf6 30. fxg6: Black resigned here because of the coming mate threat or material loss. fxg6,..hxg6, Rf1+,..Ke6, Qg7!  Black couldn't move properly after 9)...Bxc3 due to his dark- squared weaknesses.
